description: From Middle English gaderen, from Old English gaderian (“to gather, assemble”), from Proto-West Germanic *gadurōn (“to bring together, unite, gather”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰedʰ- (“to unite, assemble, keep”).

entries.meaning: A plait or fold in cloth, made by drawing a thread through it; a pucker.
The inclination forward of the axle journals to keep the wheels from working outward.
The soffit or under surface of the masonry required in gathering. See gather (transitive verb).
(glassblowing) A blob of molten glass collected on the end of a blowpipe.

verbs.description: gather (third-person singular simple present gathers, present participle gathering, simple past and past participle gathered)

examples: We went to gather some blackberries from the nearby lane.

entries.meaning: To accumulate over time, to amass little by little.
examples: Over the years he'd gathered a considerable collection of mugs.
People gathered round as he began to tell his story.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To grow gradually larger by accretion.
examples: Their snow-ball did not gather as it went.

definitionGroups.group: To bring parts of a whole closer.

entries.meaning: (sewing) To add pleats or folds to a piece of cloth, normally to reduce its width.
examples: A gown should be gathered around the top so that it will remain shaped.
Be careful not to stretch or gather your knitting.
If you want to emphasise the shape, it is possible to gather the waistline.

entries.meaning: (architecture) To bring together, or nearer together, in masonry, as for example where the width of a fireplace is rapidly diminished to the width of the flue.
(nautical) To haul in; to take up.
examples: to gather the slack of a rope

entries.meaning: To infer or conclude; to know from a different source.
examples: From his silence, I gathered that things had not gone well.
I gather from Aunty May that you had a good day at the match.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, medicine, of a boil or sore) To be filled with pus
examples: Salt water can help boils to gather and then burst.

entries.meaning: (glassblowing) To collect molten glass on the end of a tool.
